title: 108_s997
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, one of the oldest inhabited areas in the US, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. The adjacent portion of the river provides water to many people in New Mexico. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is vital for providing water to many people in the state and should be maintained to protect endangered species and the river flow. The Corps of Engineers aims to restore the environment and reestablish hydrologic connections between the river and the bosque. The Corps of Engineers aims to restore the hydrologic connection between the Middle Rio Grande and the Middle Rio Grande bosque to ensure healthy growth of native vegetation. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "critical restoration project" as a project that will provide immediate ecosystem benefits, "Middle Rio Grande" as a specific portion of the Rio Grande in New Mexico, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Army. The Secretary will implement critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande based on feasibility studies and existing plans to involve local participation. The Secretary will consult with public and private entities active in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed, including the Middle Rio Grande Endangered Species Act Collaborative Program and the Bosque Improvement Group of the Middle Rio Grande Bosque Initiative, before implementing critical restoration projects. Cost-sharing agreements will be established before project implementation. Before carrying out any critical restoration project under the Bosque Initiative, the Secretary shall enter into a cost-sharing agreement with non-Federal interests. The agreement will require non-Federal interests to pay 25% of the total project costs, provide necessary land and materials, and cover 100% of the operation expenses. The Secretary shall enter into a cost-sharing agreement with non-Federal interests for critical restoration projects under the Bosque Initiative. Non-Federal interests must pay 100% of operation, maintenance, repair, replacement, and rehabilitation costs incurred after the enactment of this Act and hold the United States harmless from any claims or damages, except for negligence by the Federal Government or its contractors. The Bosque Initiative requires non-Federal interests to pay for operation, maintenance, and other costs for critical restoration projects. They must also hold the United States harmless, except for damages caused by the negligence of the Federal Government or its contractors. Recreational features in these projects should not exceed 30% of the total project cost, with non-Federal interests responsible for any additional costs. Non-Federal interests are responsible for paying for restoration projects exceeding the specified amount. They can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if the work they perform is deemed integral to the project. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
